chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Staphylococcal carriage
chapter.summary: Covers the management of staphylococcal carriage and colonization, including when and whom to swab, and the decolonization procedure.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 1 month onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I swab for staphylococcal carriage?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Take swabs from the contents of the boil or carbuncle.
  • If recurrent boils or carbuncles are localized to the facial area, swab the nasal cavity.
  • If the boils or carbuncles are more extensive, consider swabbing the perineum, groin, axillae and umbilicus in addition to the nose.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the expert opinion of our reviewers including those from the British Association of Dermatologists.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I decolonize a person with confirmed staphylococcal carriage?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Do not start decolonization until acute infection has resolved.
  • Ensure that the person understands preventative measures to reduce the risks of future infections following decolonization.
  • Eliminate nasal carriage by prescribing Naseptin® cream (chlorhexidine plus neomycin), four times a day for 10 days. Be aware that Naseptin® contains arachis oil (peanut oil) and should not be used by a person known to be allergic to peanuts or soya.
    • If Naseptin® cream is unsuitable or not effective, consider prescribing mupirocin nasal ointment, three times daily for 5 days.
    • If both mupirocin and Naseptin® are ineffective, seek expert advice.
  • If the person has a confirmed PVL skin infection, discuss their management with microbiology or the local infection control team.
  • All people requiring decolonization should be advised about treatment for the skin:
    • Use an antiseptic preparation (such as chlorhexidine 4% body wash/shampoo or Triclosan 2%) daily as liquid soap in the bath, shower, or sink for 5 days.
      • Avoid diluting beforehand in water as this will reduce its efficacy.
      • Apply directly to wet (never dry) skin on a disposable wipe or by using the hand.
      • Allow it to remain on the skin for about 1 minute.
      • Rinse off thoroughly and dry skin well.
      • Additionally, use as a shampoo on the first, third, and fifth day.
      • Avoid using regular soap in addition to the antiseptic during baths/showers.
      • Pay particular attention to the axillae, groins, buttocks, under the breasts, and the hands.
  • If a person with a dermatological condition, such as eczema, requires treatment for the skin, seek a dermatological opinion.
  • Whilst the skin treatment is being used for 5 days, advise the person to reduce the household spread of staphylococcus by:
    • Changing sheets and towels daily. Wash sheets, towels, and underwear regularly on a hot wash cycle (above 55°C). The clothes should be turned inside out and the machine not overloaded so that the water can circulate.
    • Vacuuming and dusting regularly, particularly in the bedrooms.
    • Using pump-action liquid soap and avoiding bar soaps.
    • Using his or her own towel and flannel, and rinsing the flannel in hot water before use.
    • Cleaning the sinks and bath with a disposable cloth and detergent after use and rinsing clean.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Which antiseptic preparation should I prescribe?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• A solution of chlorhexidine 4% or triclosan 1-2% is generally suitable. For example:
    • Hibiscrub® and Hydrex® Surgical Scrub.
    • Oilatum® plus.
  • Consider Dermol® for people with skin conditions or delicate skin.
    • This is less likely to irritate the skin, although contact sensitization to the antiseptic component may still occur with prolonged use.
  • Consider seeking a dermatological opinion for people with skin conditions.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Waiting until acute infection has resolved
  • Decolonization will not be effective if skin lesions are still leaking; therefore it is important to wait until infection has resolved [HPA, 2010]. The purpose of decolonization is to rid the body of bacteria that have caused recurrent boils or carbuncles [HPA, 2008a].
Nasal decolonization
  • The recommendation to use Naseptin® cream first line is based on the expert opinion of reviewers from the British Association of Dermatologists. The British National Formulary also recommends that mupirocin should probably be held in reserve for resistant cases [BNF 72, 2016].
  • Expert opinion in a textbook [Pasternack and Swartz, 2010] recommends the use of mupirocin cream for the elimination of staphylococcal carriage. Application of mupirocin 2% into the anterior nares is highly effective in eliminating Staphylococcus aureus in both healthy carriers and carriers in at-risk groups. Mupirocin has broad-spectrum activity against Gram-positive bacteria including S. aureus, and is well tolerated when used twice daily for up to 5 days [Blaser, 2010].
  • Mupirocin is recommended by the Health Protection Agency (HPA) for the elimination of PVL-SA carriage which may sometimes be associated with recurrent boils and carbuncles [HPA, 2008a; HPA, 2008b; HPA, 2010].
  • The recommendation to seek specialist advice if both mupirocin and Naseptin® are ineffective is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Naseptin and soya
  • The manufacturers recommend that Naseptin® is avoided in people with peanut allergies because it contains arachis oil. As there is a possible relationship between allergy to peanut and allergy to soya, people with soya allergy should also avoid using Naseptin®.
Discussing the management of confirmed PVL skin infection with microbiology or the local infection control team.
  • This is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.
Skin treatment
  • This recommendation is based on the decolonization procedures for PVL-SA recommended by the Health Protection Agency [HPA, 2008a; HPA, 2008b].
Reducing the spread of staphylococci within the household
  • This recommendation is based on the decolonization procedures for PVL-SA recommended by the Health Protection Agency [HPA, 2008a; HPA, 2008b].
Choice of antiseptic preparation

  • This recommendation is based on the decolonization procedures for PVL-SA recommended by the Health Protection Agency [HPA, 2008a; HPA, 2008b].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What should I do if there is still recurrence of boils or carbuncles despite treating staphylococcal carriage?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Take a history in case any family member is a hospital or health care worker.
  • If there are recurrent boils or carbuncles consider:
    • Extending swabbing to exclude carriage at other sites such as perineum, groin, axillae, and umbilicus, if only the nose has been swabbed initially.
    • Specifically requesting testing for PVL-SA.
    • Identifying and treating potential sources of infection in the family and close contacts.
    • Screening household members if they are willing to co-operate with an eradication strategy. However, this may be difficult to organize in primary care.
  • If the person has MRSA, see the CKS topic on MRSA in primary care for further information.
  • If the person has PVL-SA infection, discuss with microbiology or the local infection control team.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the opinion of our expert reviewers including those from the British Association of Dermatologists and on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.

Mentioning PVL-SA on the laboratory form
  • This is based on expert opinion in an article [Fogo, 2011]. PVL gene detection is not routinely tested in the UK, and antibiotic sensitivities cannot reliably discriminate between PVL positive and negative strains of S. aureus.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What should I advise about prevention of further staphylococcal reinfection?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Advise the person to:
    • Take a daily shower or bath.
    • Wash hands regularly with soap and water.
    • Change clothes and underclothes regularly.
    • Avoid sharing towels, face cloths, razors, toothbrushes, and water bottles.
    • Wash sports clothes after use each time.
    • Use disposable tissues to blow their nose and avoid picking their nose.
    • In saunas and gyms, to sit on a clean towel and wash the towel after use.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: • These recommendations are standard prevention measures recommended by the Health Protection Agency to prevent staphylococcal infection [HPA, 2009].
